titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Annina Nosei Gallery Archive
1963-2009
MSS.298
titlestmt.author: Lawrence Giffin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-11-30 11:03:28 -0500.

did.abstract: The Annina Nosei Gallery was a New York City art gallery from 1981 to 2005. The Annina Nosei Gallery Archive comprises the records produced and used by the gallery; it also includes records of Annina Nosei's private acquisitions and sales, as well as her work as a curator/dealer before and after the Annina Nosei Gallery.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p:
Based in SoHo for fifteen years, Annina Nosei Gallery moved to Chelsea in 1995, closing in 2005. The gallery was instrumental in introducing the work of Neo Expressionist Italian and German figurative painters, as well as young American painters, to a market largely dominated by minimalism and conceptual art. From its inception until its closing in 2005, the Annina Nosei Gallery continued to promote young, emerging artists.
Annina Nosei was born in Rome, Italy. She received doctorates in literature and philosophy from the University of Rome, where she studied under the art historian Giulian Carlo Argan and wrote her thesis on Marcel Duchamp. She received a Fulbright in 1964 to study in the United States, where she taught at the University of Michigan and later at UCLA, St. John's University in Manhattan, and Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn.
While teaching at UCLA in 1965, Nosei met the art dealer John Weber, to whom she was married from 1966 to 1973. Her first gallery experience was in helping to organize and install exhibitions at Weber's gallery in Los Angeles. In 1979, Nosei began to show and deal art in a loft owned by Larry Gagosian at 421 West Broadway, New York City, across the street from the Leo Castelli Gallery. In 1980, Nosei opened her own gallery in SoHo at 100 Prince Street. In 1995, the gallery moved to 530 West 22nd Street, in Chelsea, and closed in 2005.
Nosei is known for being the first dealer to represent Jean-Michel Basquiat from 1981 to about 1983, and for providing him with materials and a space to work in the basement of the gallery. Though known primarily for representing German and American Neo-Expressionists and Italian New Image painters, the Annina Nosei Gallery represented and exhibited a diverse range of artists, such as Ghada Amer, Julio Galan, Tsibi Geva, Graciela Hasper, Barbara Kruger, Robert Longo, Alan McCollum, Shirin Neshat, and Jenny Watson.
Sources:
Chernow, Burt. (2000). Christo and Jeanne-Claude: a biography. New York: St. Martin's Press.
(2002). The New York Times Guide to the Arts of the 20th Century, Vol. IV, 1980-1989. Chicago: Fitzroy Dearborn Publishers.
Krantz, Les. (1985). American art galleries: the illustrated guide to thir art and artists. New York: Facts on File Publications.
Private communication with Annina Nosei, March 16, 2011.
Smith, Roberta. (June 1, 2008). "John Weber, 75, Contemporary-Art Dealer, Is Dead." The New York Times. From http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/01/arts/design/01weber.html
Thompson, Donald N. (2008). The $12 million stuffed shark: the curious economics of contemporary art. London: Aurum Press.
de Coppet, L. & Jones, A. (1984). The Art Dealers. New York: Cooper Square Press.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Series were created by the archivist based on discussions with Annina Nosei and on a careful appraisal of the material. Each series reflects an explicit function of the Annina Nosei Gallery in its daily activities of taking artworks on consignment; of buying, selling, and shipping artworks; of planning and executing exhibitions in its gallery space as well as at museums, art fairs, and other galleries; and of managing, promoting, and paying represented artists. Every effort was made to retain the original order of the files. The subseries reflect the titles and organization of records by the gallery.
Almost all subseries titles were originated by the gallery as it created and maintained its records (and were printed on hanging files in labeled file cabinet drawers or on labeled boxes). The following four subseries were created and named by the archivist in an effort to simplify access, protect materials, and organize miscellany:

Series III, Subseries D
Series III, Subseries E
Series IV, Subseries G
Series VII, Subseries C
Folders: Original folders were replaced with acid-free folders. Unless in brackets, all folder titles are taken from the original folder. A folder label in brackets is a label supplied by the archivist, either because the material was not foldered or because the original folder was unlabeled. The archivist has striven to replicate the gallery's naming conventions where they could be discerned.

Each folder in the archive holds the entire contents of an original folder. If there was more material in an original folder than would fit in a new folder, that material is divided between two or more folders, each folder bearing the original folder's name followed by the convention "[1/4]," "[2/4]," etc. If two different folders share the same name, each will be followed by a number in brackets denoting its position in a series/subseries (e.g., "[1]," "[2]," etc.).
Binders: Unless in brackets, all binder labels are taken from the original binders. All materials separated from binders are foldered according to their original grouping in a single binder sleeve (most of which contained several items).
Photocopies: All thermal paper has been replaced with a photocopied surrogate. Original folders bearing writing have been photocopied, and the photocopy has been placed at the end of the new folder. Items bearing sticky notes were photocopied, the sticky notes were removed, and the photocopies refiled with the originals (usually attached to it with a plastic clip).
Dates: All dates are approximate and provided by the archivist based on a cursory glance at the contents of each folder.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection, including for research purposes, must be secured from Annina Nosei or her legal designee. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
The Annina Nosei Gallery Archive comprises the records produced by the Annina Nosei Gallery in the day-to-day course of its business functions. The archive also includes records of Annina Nosei's private acquisitions and sales, as well as her work as a curator/dealer before and after the Annina Nosei Gallery. Materials include invoices and receipts for works bought and sold by the gallery or by Annina Nosei personally; administrative records for the Annina Nosei Gallery; photographic prints, transparancies, slides, and negatives; correspondence with artists, dealers, collectors, critics, curators, and other art institutions; promotional and exhibition materials (artist bios, magazine advertisements, exhibition announcements), and periodicals and clippings that feature artists represented by the gallery.
Series Description The Annina Nosei Gallery Archive is divided into nine series.
Series I: Transaction Records comprises files created in the gallery's process of buying artworks, taking artworks on consignment, and selling artworks. The series is divided into ten subseries.

Subseries A: Consignment Files
Subseries B: Inventory Cards: Works Sold
Subseries C: Inventory Cards: Returned to Artist
Subseries D: Inventory Books
Subseries E: Collector's Books
Subseries F: Artist Books
Subseries G: Acquisitions Receipts
Subseries H: Invoices
Subseries I: Shipment Records
Subseries J: Accounting
Series II: Correspondence comprises correspondence sent and received by the Annina Nosei Gallery. The series is divided into five subseries.
Subseries A: Collectors
Subseries B: Dealers
Subseries C: Museum and Universities
Subseries D: Art Fairs/Auction Houses
Subseries E: Magazines, Critics, and Curators
Series III: Artist Files comprises paper documents (including artists' bios, price lists, clippings, correspondence, exhibition announcements) and photographic materials relating to artists represented by the gallery and shows held at the gallery. The series is divided into six subseries.

Subseries A: General Artist Files
Subseries B: Master Slides Binders
Subseries C: Visuals Binders
Subseries D: Material Separated from Master Slides Binders
Subseries E: Material Separated from Visuals Binders
Subseries F: Polaroids
Series IV: Jean-Michel Basquiat Artist File comprises artist biographies and other promotional material, price lists, invoices, correspondence, phone bills, bank account records, photographic material, and periodicals and clipping relating to Jean-Michel Basquiat, his work, and his relationship with the Annina Nosei Gallery. The series is divided into ten subseries.

Subseries A: Artist Files
Subseries B: Correspondence
Subseries C: Accounting
Subseries D: Invoices
Subseries E: Slides Binder
Subseries F: Visuals Binders
Subseries G: Material Separated from Visuals Binders
Subseries H: Polaroids
Subseries I: Catalogs
Subseries J: Periodicals, Clippings
Series V: Exhibition Records comprises materials related to each show held at the Annina Nosei Gallery. Materials include installation photographs, price lists, artist bios, exhibition cards, press clippings. The series is divided into nine subseries.

Subseries A: Annina Nosei Gallery Shows; 1982-1983, 1983-1984
Subseries B: Annina Nosei Gallery Shows; September 1984 - August 1986
Subseries C: Annina Nosei Gallery Shows; October 1986 to December 1989 (included [sic]
Subseries D: Annina Nosei Gallery Shows; January 1990 - July 1992
Subseries E: Exhibitions; October 1992 - Jan 1993 - 94 - 96
Subseries F: Exhibitions Record; Jan 1997 - Dec 1999
Subseries G: Exhibition Records Jan. 2000 -
Subseries H: Catalogs
Subseries I: Guest Books
Series VI: Other Administrative Files comprises material related to the general day-to-day administration of the gallery itself and the gallery space. The series is divided into three subseries.

Subseries A: Planners
Subseries B: Memos
Subseries C: Gallery Space
Series VII: Pre-gallery Curating comprises material drawn from exhibitions curated by Nosei prior to opening her gallery.
Series VIII: Misc. Artist Publications, Periodicals, Clippings comprises some monographs of artists represented by the gallery, some periodicals that include artists represented by the gallery, and various clippings, all accumulated and stored by the gallery.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Annina Nosei Gallery Archive; MSS 298; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises files created in the gallery's process of buying works, taking works on consignment, and selling works.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: The subseries reflect the gallery's original organization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries comprises files created by the gallery when taking works on consignment.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged in its original order.

did.unittitle: Subseries B: Inventory Cards: Works Sold

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
Subseries comprises index cards created for each artwork sold by the gallery. Each card displays that artwork's inventory number and invoice number, which can also be found on corresponding records in this series. The cards are color coordinated.
Pink card: The work was given to Annina Nosei, that is, she did not buy it. There was no money involved. On many of these cards you will find written the word "gift."
Blue card: The work was bought by the Gallery. Most cards denote the amount paid.
White card: The work was consigned to the gallery either by the artist, another dealer, another gallery, or a collector.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged in its original order. The index cards were originally contained in file drawers labeled "Works Sold" followed by an alphabetical range. This naming convention has been replicated here (e.g., the cards under the heading "Works Sold A-F" were originally held together in one file drawer labeled "Works Sold A-F"). The ranges of artists contained in each box has been provided by the archivist in the space below the box number.

did.unittitle: Subseries C: Inventory Cards: Returned to Artist

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
Subseries comprises index cards created for each artwork that the gallery attempted to sell but could not and returned to the artist. Each card displays that artwork's inventory number, which can also be found on corresponding records in this series. The cards are color coordinated.
Pink card: The work was given to Annina Nosei, that is, she did not buy it. There was no money involved. On many of these cards you will find written the word "gift."
Blue card: The work was bought by the Gallery. Most cards denote the amount paid.
White card: The work was consigned to the gallery either by the artist, another dealer, another gallery, or a collector.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged in its original order. The index cards were originally contained in file drawers labeled "RTA" (which stands for "Returned to Artist") followed by an alphabetical range. This naming convention has been replicated here (e.g., the cards under the heading "RTA A-D-F" were originally held together in one file drawer labeled "RTA A-D-F"). The ranges of artists contained in each box has been provided by the archivist in the space below the box number.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged in numerical order by inventory number. Folders are labeled with the title on front of the original ledger.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises ten twelve-column ledgers organized by the inventory number assigned to each artwork. Each entry in each ledger gives the inventory number, the artist's name, the work's title, the date the work was received by the gallery, the year the work was executed, the size of the work, the artist's price, the consignee, the work's medium, the gallery's suggested price, amount owed to the gallery, and the work's current location including to whom it sold or if it was returned to the artist.

did.unittitle: Gallery Inventory Book no 2; From #6024 through 7401
Gallery Inventory Book no. 3; from #7402 through 8021
Gallery Inventory Books no. 4; from #8022 to #8515
Gallery Inventory Book no. 5; from #8516 to 9131
Gallery Inventory Book no. 6; from 9132 to 9703

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
According to the gallery, Collector's Books and Artist Books are different forms of the same function. At a cursory glance, Collector's Books comprises ledgers that seem to document what artist's work (by invoice number) was sold to what collector (whether individual or institution), while Artist Books comprises small spiral-bound notebooks listing the names, addresses, and phone numbers (sometimes in the form of business cards affixed to the pages) of persons and institutions interested in purchasing the work of certain artists. Often in Artist Books, a name and address will be accompanied by a note that reads "interested in 'X work of art'."
The ledger sheets in Collector's Book A-I and Collector's Book J-O are from National brand top-lock post binders. Collecto'rs Book P-Z is from a Six Star brand top-lock post binder.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged in its original order. Ledger sheets were originally contained in large top-lock post binders and divided alphabetically by tabbed dividers. That arrangement has been replicated here at the folder level. The labels "Collector's Book A-I," "Collector's Book J-O," and "Collector's Book P-Z" were copied from labels on the binders themselves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: According to the gallery, Collector's Books and Artist Books are different forms of the same function. At a cursory glance, Collector's Books comprises ledgers that seem to document what artist's work (by invoice number) was sold to what collector (whether individual or institution), while Artist Books comprises small spiral-bound notebooks listing the names, addresses, and phone numbers (sometimes in the form of business cards affixed to the pages) of persons and institutions interested in purchasing the work of certain artists. Often in Artist Books, a name and address will be accompanied by a note that reads "interested in 'X work of art'."

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged alphabetically by first artist's last name printed on the front of the book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises invoices for works sold by the gallery. Invoices [contain] inventory numbers and invoice numbers that can be matched with those found in Series I, Subseries A, B, E, and F. The final folder in this series, ["Gallery Policies"], while not an invoice, was originally filed with the invoices, so has remained in this series.

Material in this subseries was originally in one of two binders. A General Note accompanying each folder description indicates to which of the two binders the contents belong.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Folder labelled "Fire '88," which was originally filed at the end of Series II, Subseries E, has been moved to Series VII, Subseries C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises paper documents (including artists' bios, price lists, clippings, correspondence, exhibition announcements) and photographic materials relating to artists represented by the gallery and shows held at the gallery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries comprises files kept by Annina Nosei Gallery on artists both represented and not represented by the gallery. Materials include clippings, gallery-produced artist's biographies, photographs, correspondence, and exhibition announcements and other promotional material.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Folders in this subseries were stored in two different ways: the majority filed alphabetically in filing cabinets and the rest filed by artist in cardboard boxes and letter boxes. Since, according to Annina Nosei, the only reason for the different filing systems was lack of space in the filing cabinets, folders from boxes are interfiled alphabetically with the folders from the filing cabinets.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: This subseries originally consisted of four large binders labeled "Master Slides A-C," "Master Slides C-G," "Master Slides H-M," "Master Slides M-O," and "Master Slides P-Z." This original arrangement has been preserved while the slides were transferred to new, archivally sound sleeves and rehoused in acid-free binders. The material in the binders is divided by tabbed dividers arranged by artists' names.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries comprises master slides kept by the Annina Nosei Gallery.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p:
This subseries originally comprised one binder per artist. This original arrangement has been preserved while the visual materials were transferred to new, archivally sound sleeves and rehoused in acid-free binders.
The original binder labels have been reproduced here, except for what appears between brackets ("[ ]"), such information was provided by the archivist for ease of use.
Some transparencies were originally sleeved in mylar, labeled, and placed in one of eight numbered pockets in a single mylar sleeve. For preservation reasons, the original sleeve was discarded. The transparencies are placed in archivally sound plastic sleeves, and a note is included that reproduces the original numbering, usually in the form, "From Binder Sleeve Pocket Numbered 'x.'"
Many of the original sleeves in the binders contained several [elements]. Each [element] has been separated out, placed in its own sleeve, and placed in a new binder following a cover sheet giving the original binder sleeve's order (e.g., Binder Sleeve 2/7), the series and subseries, and the name of the artist as it appeared on the original binder.
When an original sleeve or binder pocket contained a large majority of paper-based [elements], everything in that sleeve or pocket was removed and placed in a folder that can be found in ["Subseries D: Material Separated"].
If the original sleeve or pocket contained a large amount of photographic material as well as paper-based material, then the paper material is removed to a folder labelled with the binder's name followed by the phrase "From Binder Sleeve x/y," and the photographic material is resleeved and arranged as described above.
In some cases, a binder sleeve with four pockets will contain four or more 3"x5" transparencies in plastic sleeves with a card or sticker taped to the sleeve giving the piece's name and dimensions. Each individually sleeved transparency is taken out of its sleeve and placed in an archival three-pocket mylar sleeve. The original plastic sleeve, if it has bears notations, is placed in the same sleeve as the transparency, along with the card or sticker that bears infomation on the artwork pictured.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The entire contents of [Izumi Chiaraluce Binder] have been moved to Series III, Subseries E, and will not appear in Series III, Subseries C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises visual materials (photographic prints, transparencies, slides, negatives, etc.) and other promotional material (including artists' bios and price lists) accumulated by the Annina Nosei Gallery.

did.unittitle: Subseries D: Material Separated from Master Slides Binders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises mostly photographic prints and transparencies, with some slides, polaroids, and paper materials, used to inventory and promote works sold through Annina Nosei Gallery.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: The order of folders in this subseries follows the order of binders in Series III, Subseries B. Artists' names in folder titles below that appear in brackets (e.g., "[From "Jose Bedia"]")were taken from the tabbed dividers that originally organized the material in the binders.

did.unittitle: Master Slides A-C [From "Mike Bidlo;" Alighiero Boetti"]
Subseries E: Material Separated from Visuals Binders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries comprises material separated from Series III, Subseries C, due to some aspect of the material that made it unsuitable to be placed in a binder.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: The order of folders in this subseries follows the order of binders in Series III, Subseries C. Each folder represents one binder sleeve; for example, when all the material has been removed from the ninth sleeve of the "Pizzi Cannella" binder in Subseries C, it is placed in a folder, which is then labeled "Pizzi Cannella [Binder Sleeve 9/12]." When only some of the material is removed from a sleeve, it is noted in the folder title as "[From Binder Sleeve x]" (e.g., Pizzi Cannella [From Binder Sleeve 4/12]").

scopecontent.head: General Note
scopecontent.p: The folder labeled "[Izumi Chiaraluce Binder]" contains the entirety of the binder since it is mostly paper material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises Polaroid instant photographs from a box labeled "Polaroids."

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Polaroid photographs were originally sorted with dividers. The original order has been maintained, including the dividers. The labels of the dividers have been preserved here. Where Polaroids from one artist were found under another artist's label, or when there are no labeled dividers (as in the beginning of Binder BC), the artist's name has been provided in brackets by the archivist to aid the researcher.

did.unittitle: Series IV: Jean-Michel Basquiat Artist File

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises artist bios and other promotional material, price lists, invoices, correspondence, phone bills, bank account records, photographic material, and periodicals and clipping relating to Jean-Michel Basquiat, his work, and his relationship with the Annina Nosei Gallery.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged in its original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Correspondence mostly regarding Basquiat and Basquiat work. Three small pieces of correspondence from Basquiat.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged in its original order.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Contains two letters signed by Basquiat.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged in its original order.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises materials related to each show held at the Annina Nosei Gallery. Materials include installation photographs, price lists, artist bios, exhibition cards, press clippings, catalogs, and guest books.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p:
Exhibition Records: Subseries A-G comprise what the gallery termed "Exhibition Records," a term denoting all materials produced and collected in connection with a specific exhibition. These records were originally sleeved in binders. Material has been removed from binder sleeves and binders and placed in folders and boxes. Titles of binders have been retained in the titles of subseries.
Materials in these subseries are arranged in the order in which they were filed in their original binders, which is reverse chronological order for each binder. The binders (subseries) themselves have been ordered chronologically by the archivist.
Each folder represents a specific exhibition (e.g., all of the material relating to the Barbara Kruger March 5-26, 1983 show is put into one folder), regardless of how many binder sleeves the material orignally occupied. Most binders were accompanied by a list of binder contents listing the exhibitions included in the date range for that binder. These lists, where available, were used by the archivist to create folder titles. Where these lists were absent, the archivist has supplied folder titles by referring to the chronological lists found in the yearly catalogs for the gallery.
Some consecutive exhibitions are represented by very little material. In such a case, that material is placed in a single folder, which is labelled with the artists' names and show titles separated by semicolons (e.g., "[Stephen Mueller; Keith Milow; Group Show; Keith Haring]").
Catalogs: Subseries H comprises catalogs created by the gallery to accompany each exhibition.
Guest Books: Subseries I comprises guest books signed by gallery patrons.

did.unittitle: Subseries A: Annina Nosei Gallery Shows; 1982-1983, 1983-1984
[Stephen Mueller; Keith Milow; Group Show; Keith Haring]
[Unlabelled Polaroids from Binder Sleeve of Pre-gallery Curating]

[Summer Group Show; Marta Maria Perez Bravo; Jenny Watson; Ieva Mediodia; Federico Uribe]
[Frederico Uribe; James Rosenquist; Group Show; Heidi McFall; Group Exhibition]
[Paolo W Tamburella; Federico Uribe; Summer Group Exhibition; Myriam Laplante; Heidi McFall; David Bowes; Liliana Porter]
[Arturo Elizondo; Jose Bedia; Tsibi Geva; Summer Group Exhibition; Paolo W. Tamburella; Tristiano Di Robilant; Group Exhibition; Jenny Watson]
[Gernot Linder, Carole Benzaken; Cemin, Christian, Schwart, Federico Uribe; Graciela Hasper; Summer Invitational; Liliana Porter]
[Marta Maria Perez Bravo; Kocheisen + Hullmann; Fabian Burgos; Group Photography Exhibition]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries comprises catalogs of artists and artists' works produced regularly by the Annina Nosei Gallery. Catalogs come in the following categories: Individual Artists, "Group Shows," "7 Latin American Artists," "The Door," and Occasional Compilations of exhibitions over a span of three to five years, each of which is described as "a testimony recording a seletion of the artist I have worked with during the last three [or "five"] years."

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged chronologically by year and alphabetically within the same year.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises material related to the general day-to-day administration of the gallery itself and the gallery space.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged chronologically. Interleaved material photocopied to indicated original location. Original and photocopy are placed in back of folder.

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: Subseries is arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Memos [Fax from Lee Ortega to Mitchell Langsner]
Memos [Exhibition Cards for Jenny Watson, Helmut Middendorf, Patrick Grant]

odd.head: General
odd.p: Folder contains documents and photographs relating to a 1988 fire at the gallery. It was originally filed at the end of Series II, Subseries E, and remains physically in its original place (box 23, folder 9).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Before opening her own gallery, Annina Nosei curated exhibitions at various locations. Series comprises material drawn from the exhibitions "Discussions," "Painting," "Memory," "Angelo Savelli: Paintings & Sculpture," and comprises press releases, programs, brochures, artist bios, and an essay by Annina Nosei on Savelli.

did.unittitle: Series VIII: Misc. Periodicals and Clippings

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p:
Materials were originally grouped by artist and shelved in magazine files bearing the artist's name. That grouping is preserved, and the folder titles bear the original labels of the magazine files.
The folder "Jose Bedia [/Guillermo Kuitca]" contains material related to both Bedia and Kuitca though the original folder only listed Bedia's name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series comprises some monographs of artists represented by the gallery, some periodicals that include artists represented by the gallery, and various clippings, all accumulated and stored by the gallery.

odd.head: General

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: The folders in this accretion series and subseries are placed here by the archivist; they were not received in binders as were the first accession fo Exhibition Records. On examining the contents of each folder the archivist determined that the contents of each seemed to fit in with the material in Series V.
